html:
The Real Question Nobody's Asking

Your family in Cuba is dealing with apagones that stretch 12, 16, sometimes 20 hours. You want to help. But here's where most people get it wrong: they obsess over wattage when they should be thinking about what actually works when the grid goes dark. Solar panels are useless at night without storage. Power stations are paperweights once they're drained. The answer isn't one or the other—it's understanding what your family actually needs to survive the blackouts.

Let's cut through the marketing noise. Solar panel kits generate electricity during daylight hours. Power stations store electricity for use anytime. For Cuba, where the sun is relentless but the grid is unreliable, you need to think about this differently than someone buying for a camping trip in Vermont.

The humid, salty air near the coast eats electronics for breakfast. Customs can be... unpredictable. And whoever's receiving this needs to be able to set it up without calling you every five minutes. These aren't theoretical concerns—they're the difference between sending something useful and sending an expensive paperweight.

Here's what I've learned from digging through hundreds of reviews and specs: the "best" system depends entirely on whether your family needs to generate power, store power, or both. Most people need both. But the budget doesn't always stretch that far.

The Short Version

If you can only send one thing, send a complete solar kit with charge controller—specifically the Renogy 400W Premium Kit. It's the most Cuba-proof option: generates power, includes everything needed for setup, and has the best build quality for humid climates. But if your family already has solar panels and needs storage, that's a different conversation entirely.

See the Renogy Kit on Amazon

The One That Actually Makes Sense

Editor's Pick

Renogy Premium 400 Watt 12V Solar Kit

5★ (505 reviews) • $$$$$ tier

This is the kit reviewers consistently call "complete." Four 100W panels, a 40A MPPT charge controller (more efficient than PWM), Bluetooth monitoring, mounting brackets, and all the cables. The MPPT controller alone is worth the upgrade—it squeezes about 15-20% more power from the panels compared to cheaper PWM controllers. For Cuban conditions where every watt counts during apagones, that efficiency matters.

VERDICT: The "send it and forget it" option. Everything included, excellent build quality, and that 5-star rating isn't accidental.

Check Price on Amazon

Breaking Down What's Actually Out There

Best Value

ECO-WORTHY 400W Premium Kit

4.3★ (435 reviews) • $$$$$

Nearly identical specs to the Renogy at a slightly lower price point. Four 100W panels, 40A MPPT controller, Bluetooth module, mounting brackets. Reviews mention the instructions could be clearer, but the hardware itself performs well. If budget is tight, this delivers 95% of the Renogy experience.

VERDICT: The smart budget pick if you're okay with slightly rougher documentation.

Check Price →

ECO-WORTHY 200W Starter Kit

4.6★ (465 reviews) • $$$$$

Half the wattage, PWM controller (less efficient), but proven reliability. Good for small loads—phone charging, LED lights, small fans.

Check Price →
"800 watts sounds impressive until you realize it's spread across 8 panels that need to be wired, mounted, and connected to a charge controller you have to buy separately."

The High-Wattage Temptation

More watts = more power, right? Technically yes. But here's what the product pages don't emphasize: most high-wattage options are panels only. No charge controller, no cables, no mounting hardware. You're buying raw generating capacity that needs a complete system to actually work.

STAR 870W (2x 435W Panels)

4.2★ • $$$$$

Massive 48V/24V panels. Full-screen design maximizes surface area. But these are panels only—you'll need a compatible charge controller and battery system.

Check Price →

Callsun 800W (8x 100W Panels)

4.6★ • $$$$$

Eight panels gives flexibility in mounting configurations. Works with 12V/24V/48V/60V systems. Again, panels only—controller sold separately.

Check Price →

The catch: Shipping 8 panels to Cuba means dealing with weight, customs, and the recipient needing to source compatible controllers locally. Unless they're expanding an existing system, complete kits make more sense.

The "Just Plug It In" Fantasy

Plug and Play 800W Solar System

4.5★ (455 reviews) • $$$$$

This one's interesting. 800W of panels plus an 800W inverter, designed to plug directly into a wall outlet and feed power back into your home's electrical system. The concept is brilliant for stable grids—but Cuba's grid is anything but stable. When the power goes out, this system has nothing to feed into. It's designed for grid-tie, not off-grid survival.

VERDICT: Wrong tool for Cuba. Great for reducing your electric bill in Miami, useless during apagones.

Check Price →

How Much Solar Do They Actually Need?

Use this calculator to estimate based on typical blackout duration and what they need to keep running.

When Money Isn't the Limiting Factor

ECO-WORTHY 9.36KWH Complete System

4.4★ (445 reviews) • $$$$$ (way up there)

This is the "whole house" solution: 2,340W of panels, a 5,000W all-in-one inverter/charger, and enough capacity to actually run a refrigerator, lights, fans, and charge devices through an extended blackout. The 48V system is more efficient than 12V for this scale. Reviewers who installed it report powering entire homes during outages.

VERDICT: If you can afford it and can get it through customs, this is the real deal. But it's a project—not a gift you drop off.

The Portable Question

Sometimes you need something that folds up, travels easily, or works as a backup to a backup. These portable panels won't power a house, but they'll keep phones charged and small devices running.

DOKIO 300W Foldable

Folds to 20x38 inches, weighs 15 lbs. Includes controller and dual USB. Serious portable power.

Check Price →

ALLPOWERS 100W Foldable

4.2★ • $$$$

23% efficiency, IP66 waterproof. Compact design pairs well with power stations. Good travel option.

Check Price →

YT30 30W Solar Charger

4.3★ • $$$

Ultra-portable with QC3.0 USB and DC output. Won't run appliances but keeps devices alive.

Check Price →

Budget Panels: Worth the Savings?

If you're buying panels to add to an existing system (or your recipient already has a charge controller), these mid-range options deliver watts without the premium price tag.

18BB 800W (4x 200W) N-Type

4.3★ • $$$

N-Type cells are the newer tech—better low-light performance and longevity. Four 200W panels at mid-range pricing. Panels only.

Check Price →

STAR 100W Single Panel

4.2★ • $$$

Full-screen design, maintenance-free. Good for testing the waters or adding incremental capacity. Works with 12V or 24V systems.

Check Price →

Compare the Complete Kits

For Those Just Getting Started

200W N-Type Kit with 30A PWM Controller

4.1★ (415 reviews) • $$$$$

The N-Type monocrystalline half-cut cells are a nice touch at this price point—they handle partial shading better than traditional panels. Includes a 30A PWM controller (not as efficient as MPPT, but simpler and reliable). Good entry point for families testing solar for the first time.

VERDICT: Solid starter kit. Won't power a whole house, but proves the concept and handles essentials.

Check Price →

Estimate Your Shipping Costs

Solar panels are heavy and bulky. Factor shipping into your decision—sometimes a smaller kit makes more sense when you account for total cost.

Wait—What About Power Stations?

Here's the thing: none of the products in this comparison are standalone power stations (batteries with built-in inverters). They're all solar generation equipment. Power stations like Jackery, Bluetti, or EcoFlow are a separate category—they store power but don't generate it. For Cuba, the ideal setup combines solar panels with a battery bank. But if you can only send one, solar panels at least give your family the ability to generate power during daylight hours. A power station without solar input is just a battery that will eventually run dry.

The Bottom Line

For most families in Cuba dealing with apagones, the Renogy 400W Premium Kit hits the sweet spot: complete system, excellent build quality, efficient MPPT controller, and everything needed for installation. It won't power an air conditioner, but it'll keep lights on, phones charged, and small appliances running through the daylight hours.

If budget allows, add a battery bank separately. If budget is tight, the ECO-WORTHY 400W kit delivers nearly identical performance for less. And if you're just testing the waters, the 200W starter kits prove the concept without the commitment.
